School of Energy and Power Engineering University of Shanghai for Science and Technology Shanghai 200093 China Graphical abstract A novel selective catalytic reduction (SCR) catalyst with strong chlorine resistance ability is urgently needed to extend the catalyst life, when SCR technique is applied in plants with high chlorine content (e.g. municipal solid waste and medical waste incinerators). This study investigates the influences of typical chlorine-containing inorganic/organic compounds (i.e. hydrogen chloride (HCl) and o-dichlorobenzene (o-DCBz)) on NH3-SCR of NO over MnO x /TiO2 and MnO x -CeO2/TiO2 catalysts at low temperatures (100−250 °C). The results indicate the presence of HCl severely inhibits the NH3-SCR reaction. On one hand, the reaction between NH3 and HCl causes the deposition of NH4Cl on catalyst surface and reduces the amount of NH3; on the other hand, HCl consumes the surface acid sites which is essential to the adsorption and activation of NH3; moreover, chlorine (Cl) atom prefers to anchor on the uncoordinated metal sites that restrains the regeneration of surface reactive oxygen species and interrupts the redox cycle of catalysts. Ce addition enhances the chlorine resistance property of MnO x -CeO2/TiO2 catalyst by interacting with HCl preferentially. The negative effect of o-DCB on NH3-SCR reaction is more serious than that of HCl below 200 °C. That’s because the competitive effect between o-DCB catalytic oxidation and deNO x via NH3-SCR reaction as well as the accumulation of o-DCB incomplete oxidation byproducts on catalyst surface further aggravates the catalyst deactivation induced by Cl atom. Keywords NH3-SCR MnOx-based catalyst Chlorine poisoning Ce addition Effect of o-DCBz 1 Introduction Waste incineration has received rapid expansion in China over the last few decades since it can reduce solid waste volume and allow energy recovery. NO emissions from waste incinerators are comparable to those from coal-fired plants [1]. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) with NH3 has been proven to be an efficient post-combustion technology to control NO emissions from stationary sources [2] and, as a consequence, SCR technique is also applied for NO abatement in some waste incinerators. However, two main problems emerge during the utilization of this technique in industrial field: (1) the high active temperature (300–400 °C) of the conventional SCR catalysts (e.g. V2O5-WO3/TiO2) always requires auxiliary device and additional energy for heating the exhaust behind baghouse filter (160 °C) to achieve high NO conversions [3]; (2) the poor resistance of SCR catalysts to the inevitable deactivation induced by the complicated flue gas compositions, highly increases the catalyst replacement cost and even leads to the abnormal emission of target pollutants [4]. Therefore, a novel catalyst with excellent low-temperature activity and strong resistance to deactivation is significantly demanded for industrial application to avoid the additional energy consumption and frequent catalyst replacement. Manganese-based catalyst has been regarded as a competitive candidate for future application due to its excellent low-temperature SCR performance [5,6]. It allows the SCR device using manganese-based catalyst to be installed downstream of the baghouse filter to protect the catalyst from abrasion and corrosion. However, there is still a small number of particulates and contaminants left in the flue gas after the baghouse filter. Previous studies have reported that manganese-based catalysts are susceptible to the fly ash components including heavy metals (Pb and Cd) [7], alkali metals (Na and K) [8] and alkali earth metals (Ca and Mg) [9] as well as SO2 [10] in the flue gas. Besides that, various chlorinated contaminants generated from chlorine-containing wastes incineration [11] also reveal a deactivation effect on manganese-based catalysts. As reported, HCl concentration ranges within 200−1500 ppm in the raw flue gas of medical waste incinerators due to the high chlorine content in medical wastes [12]. Ji et al. [13] surveyed 9 municipal solid waste (MSW) incinerators and pointed out that the HCl concentration in flue gas can be controlled efficiently by means of alkaline reagents (i.e. Ca(OH)2 or NaHCO3) to fulfill the emission limit (60 mg/Nm3) of China (GB 18485−2014). However, HCl residual in flue gas still deactivates the SCR catalyst mainly due to the transformation of active components to inactive chlorinated species; the deposition of NH4Cl formed from the reaction between NH3 and HCl on catalyst surface; and the change of catalyst surface acid property [4,14]. Alkali chlorines (e.g. KCl) in flue gas shows more severe inhibition effect on SCR activity than other alkali salts (e.g. K2SO4, KNO3 and K2CO3) [15,16]. In addition, chlorinated aromatics in flue gas act as another chlorine source; nevertheless, few literatures report the impact of those compounds on NH3-SCR reaction [17]. Cerium oxide (CeO2) is frequently selected as a promoter to optimize the SCR performance of MnO x catalysts [18]. Our previous study [19] has reported that the TiO2 supported MnO x -CeO2 composite catalysts exhibits optimal low-temperature SCR performance and above 98 % of NO is abated below 200 °C. Different researches indicated that the combination of MnO x with CeO2 can form uniform MnCeO x solid solution and couple the multiple oxidation states of MnO x (Mn4+/Mn3+/Mn2+) with the fast redox cycle of CeO2 (Ce4+/Ce3+), thereby improves the SCR performance of the catalysts [5,20]. Besides that, several groups also have proposed that CeO2 modification shows promotion effect on the chlorine resistance ability of MnO x [17] and CuO x [21] catalysts. In this study, the catalytic activities of MnO x /TiO2 and MnO x -CeO2/TiO2 catalysts with or without HCl were experimentally evaluated at low temperatures. The deactivation mechanism of HCl on NH3-SCR of NO as well as the promotion effect of Ce addition on the chlorine resistance property of catalyst was explored based on the characterizations of the fresh and deactivated catalysts. Besides, the Gibbs free energy calculation was carried out to further verify the proposed deactivation mechanism. Moreover, the differences between the deactivation mechanisms of HCl and o-DCBz on NH3-SCR reaction were also contrasted in detail. 2 Experiments 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterizations The MnO x /TiO2 (with the Mn/Ti mole ratio = 0.15, notated as Mn/Ti) and MnO x -CeO2/TiO2 (with the Mn/Ti mole ratio = 0.15 and the Ce/Ti mole ratio = 0.10, notated as MnCe/Ti) catalysts were prepared using sol-gel method, which has been depicted in detail in our previous study [19]. Both the fresh Mn/Ti and MnCe/Ti catalysts and the two catalysts used after NH3-SCR reaction with 1000 ppm HCl were characterized to investigate the deactivation mechanism of HCl on catalytic activity as well as the promotion effect of Ce addition on the chlorine resistance property of catalyst. The Powder X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) of the catalysts were measured using an XRD-6100 powder diffractometer (Shimadzu, Japan) with CuK α radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm). The catalyst samples were scanned over the range of 10−80°2θ at a rate of 0.02°/min. The specific surface area and pore size distribution of the catalysts were determined at 77 K by N2-adsorption equipped with an automated Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) and pore analyzer (TRISTAR 3020, Mike Instrument Co. USA). Prior to the measurement, the samples were degassed in vacuum at 573 K for 3 h. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) with Al Ka X-rays (Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi) was employed to measure the surface atomic states (Mn, Ce, O and Cl) of the catalysts. All the binding energies in XPS were calibrated by using C1 s (284.8 eV) as a reference. Hydrogen Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR, Micromeritics Auto chem II 2920) and Ammonia Temperature Programmed Desorption (NH3-TPD, Micromeritics Auto chem II 2920) were employed to measure the reducibility and acidic property of the home-made catalysts respectively. Prior to H2-TPR, the catalyst samples (ca.70 mg) were pretreated in He at 300 °C for 2 h followed by cooling down to 50 °C. After that, the H2-TPR was implemented from 100 to 700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min in 10 % H2/Ar (50 mL/min) and the H2 consumption was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). During NH3-TPD, the catalyst samples (120 mg) were pretreated in He (50 mL/min) at 300 °C for 2 h and then cooled down to 50 °C. The adsorption step started when 10 %NH3/He purged the catalyst samples at 100 °C and the desorption of NH3 was carried out from 50 to 500 °C at a heating rate of 10◦C/min in He. The Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) spectra of the catalysts were recorded with Thermo Nicolet iS50 spectrometer equipped with a Harrick Scientiﬁc DRIFT cell, to study the surface speciation of the fresh and deactivated Mn/Ti and MnCe/Ti catalysts. The FTIR spectra were collected in the range of 400−4000 cm−1 at 4 cm−1 resolution. 2.2 Catalytic activity test Catalytic activity tests were carried out in a vertical quartz tube reactor (70 cm length, 20 mm inner diameter) under ambient pressure. The reactor with 2 mL catalyst powder was then installed inside the electric furnace with a heating system. NO (300 ppm), NH3 (300 ppm), O2 (3 %), HCl (100−1000 ppm, when added), o-DCBz (289 ppm, when added) and N2 (as balance gas) were mixed to simulate the flue gas. The constant inlet concentration of o-DCBz relied on a home-made stable generator providing gaseous o-DCBz continuously. The generator system contained a micro-injector of liquid-phase o-DCBz, a pre-heater with temperature control device and a carrier gas (N2) supplier with flow controller. The o-DCBz addition concentration was calculated from the mean value of four repeated runs (with a standard deviation of 0.6), which was quantificationally determined by a gas chromatography-mass spectrometer (GC–MS, 7890A/5975C, Agilent). The total gas flow passing through the reactor were controlled at 1000 mL/min by mass flowmeter controllers (CS200, Sevenstar Electronics Co., Ltd.), corresponding to a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 30000 h−1. The catalytic activity evaluation experiment was started when the system maintained in steady condition for 1 h and each experiment at different condition was triplicated to ensure the reliability of the experiment data. The inlet (C inlet ) and outlet (C outlet ) concentrations of NO were monitored by a Flue Gas Analyzer (Optima7.0, York Instruments Co. Ltd, Germany). The NO conversion (%) and the deactivation rate (%) are calculated as Eq.(1) and Eq.(2) respectively. Thereinto, η with HCl and η without HCl represent the NO conversions with and without HCl. (1) NO conversion (%) = (C inlet -C outlet )/C inlet ×100 % (2) Deactivation rate (%) =(η without HCl -η with HCl )/η without HCl ×100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity evaluation with or without HCl The influence of HCl on the catalytic performance towards NO reduction at different reaction temperatures was studied on Mn/Ti and MnCe/Ti catalysts. As seen from Fig. 1 , the results indicate that the presence of HCl dramatically reduces the SCR activities of the catalysts, especially for Mn/Ti catalyst. The NO conversions from Mn/Ti catalyst are declined from 31.6 %, 55.1 %, 70.0 % and 46.0 % to 6.9 %, 23.4 %, 40.5 % and 30.8 % at the temperatures of 100°C, 150°C, 200°C and 250°C respectively and the most severe condition occurs at 100 °C that the deactivation rate reaches 78 %. In comparison with Mn/Ti catalyst, higher NO conversions are achieved on MnCe/Ti catalyst with or without HCl; meanwhile, the deactivation rates obtained from MnCe/Ti catalyst are obviously lower than that of Mn/Ti catalyst at all temperatures, implying that Ce addition not only improves the catalytic activity but also enhances the chlorine resistance property of the catalyst. For both Mn/Ti and MnCe/Ti catalysts, the NO conversions without HCl increase as the temperature raises (except for the descend at 250°C due to the over oxidation of NH3 [22,23])；while the deactivation rates of each catalyst drop with the increase of the temperature, indicating that high temperature can effectively alleviate the deactivation effect of HCl on catalytic activity. Similar results have been obtained in previous studies so that the authors suggested the thermal treatment as a regeneration method for the chlorine-poisoned catalysts [24,25]. The effect of HCl concentration on the catalytic activity of MnCe/Ti catalyst is further evaluated. Fig. 2 demonstrates that the SCR activities of MnCe/Ti catalyst decrease with the increase of HCl concentration from 100 to 1000 ppm, while the deactivation rate goes up accordingly. This result manifests that the increase of HCl concentration can amplify the negative impact of HCl and aggravate the deactivation of the catalysts. 3.2 HCl poisoning mechanism discussion Several characterizations were conducted on the fresh and used Mn/Ti and MnCe/Ti catalysts to in-depth study the deactivation mechanism of HCl on NH3-SCR activity. Compared to fresh catalysts, the SBET, Vtot and Dave values of the used Mn/Ti and MnCe/Ti catalysts are all decreased after NH3-SCR reaction with 1000 ppm HCl (Table 1 ). Those changes in the structure parameters of the used catalysts can be ascribed to the deposit of NH4Cl (formed from the interaction between NH3 and HCl) on catalyst surface and the chlorination of the catalytic active components [14,26], which result in the poorer distribution of catalytic active components as well as the less contact between gaseous reactants and catalyst. However, MnCe/Ti catalyst with larger decrements in SBET and Vtot obtains lower deactivation rates instead. Therefore, the deterioration of the catalyst surface morphology is not the main reason explaining for the catalyst deactivation during the NH3-SCR reaction in the presence of HCl [10]. According to the XRD patterns of the fresh and used Mn/Ti and MnCe/Ti catalysts in Fig. 3 , the anatase rather than rutile TiO2 (PDF#21-1272) are observed as predominated phase in all the tested samples. Two weak diffraction peaks at 37.2° (PDF#31-0820) and 55.2° (PDF#41-1422) assigned to MnO2 and Mn2O3 are detected in the fresh Mn/Ti catalyst [19] while their intensities are weakened after NH3-SCR reaction with HCl, especially for the peak belonging to Mn2O3. That’s probably because the MnO x crystal structure is partially destructed due to the interaction between MnO x species and HCl. As for the fresh MnCe/Ti catalyst, no obvious reflection assigned to the fluorite structure of CeO2 can be observed except for one broad and weak peak at around 33.3° (PDF#43-1002), which attributes to (200) lattice plane of CeO2 [27,28]. In addition, MnCe/Ti catalysts also involve Ce2O3 showing a small diffraction peak at 30.2° (PDF#23-1048) [29]. Signals corresponding to Mn species disappear on the fresh MnCe/Ti catalyst due either to the high dispersion of Mn species on catalyst support or to the incorporation of Mn species into CeO2 lattice [30]. In comparison, the diffraction peak attributed to CeO2 and Ce2O3 also become weaker and broader in the used MnCe/Ti catalyst, indicating the chemical surrounding of Ce atom has been changed when the MnCe/Ti catalyst contacts with HCl. It is known that the Cl atom radius (1.62 Å) is greatly larger than that of O atom (0.66 Å). Such a transformation of MnO x (or CeO2) species peak in the used Mn/Ti (or MnCe/Ti) catalysts can be explained by that the Cl atom from HCl molecular replaces some position of the lattice oxygen to form chlorinated species (e.g., MnCl x and MnO y Cl z (or CeCl x and CeO y Cl z )) on catalyst [31], which causes the distortion of the MnO x (or CeO2) lattice. However, no reflections corresponding to the chlorinated species are detected in the used Mn/Ti and MnCe/Ti catalysts, implying the chlorinated species formed on catalyst are either in amorphous or in microcrystalline form which are difficult to be detected in XRD patterns. As known, NH3-SCR reaction is normally initiated with the chemisorption of NH3 on surface acid sites [19], hence the surface acid property of catalyst has close relationship with catalytic activity. The NH3 species anchored on Brønsted acid sites (labeled as B acid) are less thermally stable than those adsorbed on Lewis acid sites (labeled as L acid), thus the first peak below 200 °C can be assigned to the desorption of ammonium ions (NH4 +) bonded to the weak B acid and the other one above 300 °C attributes to the coordinated NH3 adsorbed on L acid [15,32]. According to Fig. 4 (a), the amounts of B acid on Mn/Ti catalyst decrease after NH3-SCR reaction with HCl. It is ascribed to the interaction between surface hydroxyl group (−OH, served as B acid sites) and HCl on catalyst surface though the condensation reaction (Eq. (3)) [33–35]. In comparison with B acid, more L acid declines on the used Mn/Ti catalyst for HCl is more likely to chemisorb on the uncoordinated metal sites of the catalyst though the reaction following Eq. (4) [26,36–38]. Both of the two reactions lead to the destruction of the surface acid sites and make against to the adsorption and activation of NH3, which result in the serious reduction of NO conversion. As for MnCe/Ti catalyst, NH3-SCR reaction with HCl barely impacts the L acid sites on catalyst surface (Fig.4(b)). The reason is that, on one hand, the uncoordinated position in Mn atom has been saturated already with the addition of Ce atom [19], which hinders the anchor of Cl atom on MnO x species; on the other hand, Ce addition prevents the MnO x species from being chlorinated by reacting with HCl preferentially [17,39] and thus keeps the surface acid sites still be available on the used MnCe/Ti catalyst. (3) Mn−OH + HCl → Mn-Cl + H2O (4) Mn-O-Mn + HCl → Mn−OH + Mn-Cl H2-TPR was conducted on the fresh and used Mn/Ti and MnCe/Ti catalysts to estimate the redox ability of the catalysts which is another critical indicator for the SCR activity [19] and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . As for fresh Mn/Ti catalyst, there are two reduction peaks are observed in the H2-TPR profile (Fig.5(a)). The first reduction peak located at 420 °C corresponds to the reduction of MnO2 or Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 and the second one centered at 598 °C refers to the reduction of Mn3O4 to MnO [40]. However, the reduction peak of the used Mn/Ti catalyst diminishes and shifts to higher temperature region. The former indicates that the oxygen storage capacity of the catalyst reduces during the chlorination process (Eq. (3) &Eq. (4)); the latter manifests the consumed surface reactive oxygen species (i.e. surface chemisorbed oxygen and surface lattice oxygen) are difficult to be regenerated [41], for the redox cycle of MnO x species is interrupted by the attack of Cl atom. Slighter negative influence of HCl on the reduction peak of MnO x species are observed in the used MnCe/Ti catalyst (Fig. 5(b)), indicating the poisoning effect of HCl on catalytic activity can be effectively resisted with the introduction of Ce. Nevertheless, the peak assigned to the reduction of CeO2 to Ce2O3 (at 575 °C) weakens evidently in the used MnCe/Ti catalyst. It confirms that the Cl atom prefers to anchor on the uncoordinated position of Ce atom rather than that of Mn atom, which prevents the Mn atom from being chlorinated and maintains the redox cycle of MnO x species. XPS was carried out to investigate the surface element contents and the metal oxidation states of catalysts. The Mn 2p spectra in Fig. 6 (a) and (b) suggest Mn species present multiple oxidation states with the binding energies at 641.1 eV (or 652.3 eV), 641.8 eV (or 653.4 eV) and 643.1 eV (or 654.5 eV) corresponding to Mn4+, Mn3+ and Mn2+ respectively [19]. For the used Mn/Ti catalyst, all peaks belonging to Mn species are shifted to higher binding energies, indicating the chlorination process changes the chemical surrounding of the Mn atom [41,42]. That’s probably because the electronegativity of Cl atom is different from that of O atom, so that the electron cloud density distribution around Mn atom alters when the adjacent O atom is replaced by Cl atom [41,42]. Furthermore, the chlorination of Mn atom also lowers the relative content of Mn4+ ions due to the electron transformation from Mn atom to Cl atom and the interruption of the conversion between Mn4+/Mn3+, which coincides with the results of H2-TPR. The Ce 3d spectra (Fig. 6(c)) can be deconvoluted into eight small peaks belonging to Ce3+ (u 1, u 2) and Ce4+ (v 1-v 6) respectively. All of the peaks in the Ce 3d spectrum of the used MnCe/Ti catalyst are shifted to higher binding energies, while no obvious change of the Mn 2p spectrum is observed for the used MnCe/Ti catalyst (Fig. 6(b)). It is another evidence proving that the Cl atom prefers to bond with Ce atom rather than with Mn atom, which interrupts the redox cycle of Ce4+/Ce3+ and protects the active MnO x species. Thereby, relatively more Mn4+ ions but less Ce4+ ions are maintained in the used MnCe/Ti catalyst (Table 2 ). Moreover, the catalyst chlorination is further ascertained from the detection of Cl atom in the XPS spectra of the used Mn/Ti and MnCe/Ti catalysts (Fig. 6(d)). The peak belonging to Cl atom shifts to relatively lower binding energy for the used MnCe/Ti catalyst, implying that the Cl atom bonds more tightly to Ce atom than to Mn atom. The O 1s spectra of the fresh Mn/Ti and MnCe/Ti catalysts contains two peaks with the binding energies at around 529.9 eV and 531.2 eV, assigned to the surface chemisorbed oxygen (Oα) and surface lattice oxygen (Oβ), respectively (Fig. 6(e) and (f)) [19]. For both Mn/Ti and MnCe/Ti catalysts, the Oα and Oβ peaks are shifted to higher binding energies after NH3-SCR reaction with HCl. That’s because the electron-withdrawing ability of Cl atom is weaker than that of O atom, hence the electron cloud density distribution in O-M-Cl structure (M denoted as Mn or Ce atom) leans more toward O atom. It is worth noting that the peak corresponding to Oβ divides into two small peaks for the used MnCe/Ti catalyst. Thereinto, the peak at around 532.2 eV corresponds to the distinctive lattice oxygen (Oβ1) involved in O-Ce-Cl bond whose electron cloud density distribution has been significantly altered due to the presence of Cl atom [43]; the other one at 529.9 eV belongs to the intrinsic lattice oxygen (Oβ2) contained in O-M-O bond which is unaffected by Cl atom. However, this phenomenon is merely observed in the used MnCe/Ti catalyst, suggesting that stronger interaction occurs between Ce atom and Cl atom. Furthermore, the reductions of surface oxygen atom concentration are observed on the used catalysts (Table 2). It proves that the chlorination of catalyst happens accompanied with the consumption of surface reactive oxygen species. To probe into the catalyst surface speciation variation during the NH3-SCR reaction with HCl, FTIR measurements were then employed. As can be seen from the FTIR spectra, bands arising from the vibration of O-H bond are observed at ∼3411 and ∼1622 cm−1 [26,44,45] in all the fresh samples (Fig. 7 ). However, the used Mn/Ti catalysts exhibit a clear decrease in the corresponding intensities of O-H bands, meanwhile a small band at 1400 cm−1 possibly assigning to the asymmetrical stretching vibrations of Mn-Cl bond appears. These observations for Mn/Ti catalyst ensure that the chlorination of catalyst consumes the surface -OH groups and forms Mn-Cl structure in MnO x lattice simultaneously due to the condensation reaction (as Eq. (3)). Nevertheless, as for the used MnCe/Ti catalyst, less decrements are observed in the intensities of O-H bands; meanwhile, no reflection belonging to Mn-Cl bond is neither detected, mainly because the chlorination of catalyst is more likely to occur on Ce atom. Unfortunately, FTIR signals assigning to the variations of CeCl x and CeO y Cl z species are absent on the used MnCe/Ti catalysts, probably attributes to the disturbance of strong band from TiO2 support, which has induced a large and intense vibration band at ∼493 cm−1 assigned to Ti-O bond. In addition to the above analysis, we also find the evidence for the preferential chlorination of Ce atom on the Gibbs free energy (ΔG) calculation of the MnO2/Mn2O3/CeO2/Ce2O3 (main phases shown in XRD patterns) reaction with HCl. Among these metal oxides, Ce2O3 is more attractive to HCl, for the ΔG values of Ce2O3 reacting with HCl are more negative than those of the other metal oxides at all the temperatures (Table 3 ), confirming the protective effect of Ce2O3 on MnO x species. Further indicated from the ΔG values, Mn2O3 and Ce2O3 are relatively easier to react with HCl than MnO2 and CeO2 (coincides with the XRD and XPS results), ensuring that the uncoordinated metal sites are more apt to receive Cl atom. Therefore, higher relative contents of Mn4+ and Ce3+ ions on catalyst surface are more conductive to enhance the chlorine resistance property of the MnCe/Ti catalyst, for the former repels the anchor of the Cl atom onto Mn atom and the latter draws the attack of Cl atom away from Mn atom. In addition, the ΔG values of the four reactions become less negative as the temperature increased from 100 to 300 °C, indicating higher temperature probably makes the chlorination of catalyst harder. This calculation results also correspond well with the activity tests shown in Fig. 1 that verifies the effectiveness of thermal treatment at higher temperature in regenerating the chlorine poisoned catalysts. 3.3 Comparison the deactivation mechanisms of HCl and o-DCBz Our previous study [19] has investigated the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism by means of the in situ Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy. We hold the opinion that the NH3 coordinated to L acid sites is effective for NO reduction and the NH3-SCR of NO over MnCe/Ti catalyst mainly follows the typical Eley-Rideal (E–R) mechanism (i.e. NH3 coordinated on L acid sites reacts directly with gaseous NO). During this process, MnO x species converts between high/low valence states, accompanied with the consumption and regeneration of the surface reactive oxygen species on catalyst. From the above analysis, the presence of HCl inhibits the NH3-SCR reaction mainly because: (1) the reaction between NH3 and HCl causes the deposition of the NH4Cl on catalyst surface and reduces the amount of NH3; (2) HCl consumes the surface acid sites that hinders the adsorption and activation of NH3; (3) HCl anchors on the uncoordinated metal sites of the catalyst by reacting with surface reactive oxygen species, which obstructs the redox cycle of the catalyst. Besides HCl, o-DCBz is another typical chlorine-containing contaminant in the flue gas from waste incinerators and has been reported to be decomposed effectively over Mn-based catalysts [46]. The effects of o-DCBz and HCl on NH3-SCR reaction over MnCe/Ti catalyst are compared in Fig. 8 . Previous investigations proposed that the catalytic oxidation of chlorobenzenes over transition metal oxide catalyst (e.g. V2O5/TiO2 and MnO x /TiO2) consists of several elementary steps [47,48]. Firstly, o-DCB adsorbs on catalyst surface by interaction with L acid sites to form π-complex of o-DCB; secondly, chlorine abstraction by nucleophilic oxygen (i.e., O2− lattice oxide ions or surface -OH groups associated with metal atoms) occurs to form phenolate intermediates; thirdly, surface reactive oxygen species (such as O2−and O− adsorbed in vacancies) attacks the aromatic ring to form oxygenate species, such as carbonate bidentate, and partially oxidized surface species, such as formates, acetates, maleates, carboxylates of the acetate type; then, the oxygenate species are further oxidized to form gas-phase reaction products (CO2, CO, H2O, HCl and Cl2); finally, gas phase oxygen (O2) adsorbs on catalyst surface to replenish the consumed surface reactive oxygen species so as to accomplish the redox cycle of the catalysts. Therefore, the negative effect of o-DCBz on NH3-SCR reaction closely relates to the catalytic oxidation of o-DCBz and is more complicated than that of HCl. As one can see in Fig. 8, o-DCBz shows more serious inhibition effect on SCR activity than HCl below 200 °C, for the former obtains higher deactivation rates with 57 % and 40 % at 175 °C and 200 °C respectively. That’s because o-DCBz catalytic oxidation induces multiple negative effects on NH3-SCR reaction. On one hand, the Cl atoms liberated from the chlorine abstraction process shows the similar poisoning effect on NH3-SCR reaction as that from HCl. On the other hand, the surface acid sites and reactive oxygen species on catalyst surface are essential for both o-DCBz catalytic oxidation and deNO x via NH3-SCR reaction. A competitive effect between NH3-SCR reaction and o-DCBz catalytic oxidation for the limited surface acid sites and reactive oxygen species arouses when o-DCBz, NO and NH3 molecules expose to catalyst surface concurrently, which further results in the reduction of NO conversion. More importantly, this competitive effect even restrains the total oxidation of o-DCBz especially at low temperature (<200 °C) and more partial oxidation byproducts residual on catalyst surface, which reduces the contact between NH3/NO and catalyst surface. However, lower deactivation rates (30 % and 18 %) are obtained for o-DCBz as the temperature raises up to 225 and 250 °C, indicating high temperature can relieve the adverse effect of o-DCBz on NH3-SCR reaction. The reason is that high temperature facilitates the complete oxidation of o-DCBz, thus reduces the residual of the incomplete oxidation byproducts on catalyst surface. Besides, the redox cycle of catalyst speeds up at high temperature so that alleviates the competitive effect between o-DCBz and NH3/NO for surface active sites. What’s more, H2O generated from the complete oxidation of o-DCBz can push the condensation reaction (Eq.(3)) towards left, which can relieve the chlorination of catalyst to some extent. 4 Conclusion The influences of HCl on NH3-SCR activities of MnO x /TiO2 and MnO x -CeO2/TiO2 catalysts were investigated based on the catalytic characterization of the fresh and deactivated catalysts. The results indicate that HCl inhibits the NH3-SCR reaction because it consumes the reactant NH3, disrupts the surface acid sites and blocks the redox cycle of catalyst. Higher HCl concentration and lower reaction temperature aggravate the deactivation effect of HCl on SCR activity. Ce addition can enhance the chlorine resistance ability of the catalyst for the Cl atom anchors preferentially on the uncoordinated position of Ce atom, which prevents the active MnO x species from being chlorinated and guarantees the regeneration of surface reactive oxygen species on catalyst surface. The negative effect of o-DCBz is more serious than that of HCl on NH3-SCR reaction, because the competitive effect between o-DCBz catalytic oxidation and NH3-SCR of NO for the limited surface acid sites and reactive oxygen species as well as the residual of the partial oxidation byproducts of o-DCBz on catalyst surface intensifies the catalyst deactivation. The poisoning mechanisms of HCl and o-DCBz proposed in this work are actually meaningful for developing low temperature SCR catalysts with strong resistance to chlorine poisoning in future. coredata.dc:description: A novel selective catalytic reduction (SCR) catalyst with strong chlorine resistance ability is urgently needed to extend the catalyst life, when SCR technique is applied in plants with high chlorine content (e.g. municipal solid waste and medical waste incinerators). This study investigates the influences of typical chlorine-containing inorganic/organic compounds (i.e. hydrogen chloride (HCl) and o-dichlorobenzene (o-DCBz)) on NH3-SCR of NO over MnO x /TiO2 and MnO x -CeO2/TiO2 catalysts at low temperatures (100−250 °C). The results indicate the presence of HCl severely inhibits the NH3-SCR reaction. On one hand, the reaction between NH3 and HCl causes the deposition of NH4Cl on catalyst surface and reduces the amount of NH3; on the other hand, HCl consumes the surface acid sites which is essential to the adsorption and activation of NH3; moreover, chlorine (Cl) atom prefers to anchor on the uncoordinated metal sites that restrains the regeneration of surface reactive oxygen species and interrupts the redox cycle of catalysts. Ce addition enhances the chlorine resistance property of MnO x -CeO2/TiO2 catalyst by interacting with HCl preferentially. The negative effect of o-DCB on NH3-SCR reaction is more serious than that of HCl below 200 °C. That’s because the competitive effect between o-DCB catalytic oxidation and deNO x via NH3-SCR reaction as well as the accumulation of o-DCB incomplete oxidation byproducts on catalyst surface further aggravates the catalyst deactivation induced by Cl atom.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of HCl and o-DCBz on NH3-SCR of NO over MnO x /TiO2 and MnO x -CeO2/TiO2 catalysts
